@Pinsir52: Wrong, it's actually the other way around.  While Ancestral Vision does have a CMC of 0, as one isn't listed, that does not mean it costs 0 to play.  As there is no mana cost listed on Vision, you can't play it from your hand, as you can't pay a non-existent cost.  This means that the only way to play Ancestral Vision is to either cheat it out (which will probably cost you more than it would to just pay U for Recall) or use the Suspend cost, which is, surprise surprise, the same amount of mana it costs to play Ancestral Recall.  Long story short, Recall is better because in the end they're going to cost you the same amount of mana, but Recall comes into effect when you pay the cost while Visions goes off four turns later.  Ancestral Vision was printed pretty much for the sole purpose of making a balanced version of Ancestral Recall.

Richard Garfield said once that the reason he was OK with the Power 9 was that he didn't think the game would get as big as it did. He basically thought it would stay small so it wouldn't matter much. The part about finding them wasn't all it.

@Guest57443454: There is nothing broken with this and Worldgorger Dragon.When Worldgorger Dragon is in any graveyard and you cast this targetting it, Worldgorger Dragon comes to play with this attached to it as an enchantment. The comes into play ability of Worldgorger Dragon triggers and when it resolves all other permanents you control are exiled. This includes the Animate Dead that is enchanting the Worldgorger Dragon. When that happens Animate Dead's triggered ability goes into stack and when it resolves the Worldgorger Dragon is put into its owners graveyard. This triggers Worldgorger Dragon's second ability and when it resolves all your permanents that the Worldgorger Dragon exiled are returned to the battlefield. Now as a state based effect the Animate Dead finds that it is not enchanting anything and goes to your graveyard. End result is that you hope your other permanents has nifty comes into play or removed from the play abilities.

This is an interesting concept of card. It certainly FEELS like a really Egyptian Curse, which is neat. I like that even though we've never had an explicitly Egyptian Block, there's a lot of cards in Magic that have an Egyptian/Dr. Fate kind of feel to them :)
The problem with this card is that being of low converted mana cost, it encourages you to play it early, and that does hurt you much, and you really should never play this in Multiplayer.
I think {3} is a great number to cast this for, since that could come down early if you have a plan to get around the two-edgedness, but if you don't have enough support and want to throw this down to stop ALL the lands and rely on the lands you have in play, then it's still castable early enough to hurt people but you don't feel like a putz for waiting til turn 5 to cast it.
I think that it would also just be neat and cool if this was able to sacrifice itself to gain you 2 life, as a one-shot way to make it better for you than your opponent. We've come along way and realized that [autocard]Wrath of God[/autocard] is very good, and making things too one-sided like with [autocard]Balance[/autocard] is very bad, but most cards should clearly sit somewhere in the middle and basically be something to give you advantage if you play it. As is, this doesn't clearly give you advantage so much as Declare a New Rule for everyone that accelerates the game to end faster. Cards like that are...alright, but usually making tiny tweaks so that the effects aren't REALLY even is a Good Thing, if you don't go overboard and make lots of [autocard]Balance[/autocard]s.
I want this to feel like an ARTIFACT, not a Red, White, or Black card, if possible. 3 CMC plus the sac clause would make it less like a White New Rule card, less like a Red All In card, and the lifegain would help keep it feeling more Artifact-y than Black :)

@EvilCleavage Land destruction has always been a part of Standard competitive play. Some of the modern (post-Stone Rain) examples are Ghost Quarter, Avalanche Riders, Primal Command, Spreading Seas, Tectonic Edge, and each of these was/has been a big player in the format.
I don't like because it destroys your lands too.  I know if the amount of mana you and your opponent have easily favors your opponent, it's a good card to have, but othwise it's horrible.
Pussies. LD is awesome, and Desolation Angel is the sexist card in MTG.

Many people consider land destruction to be "unfun," but it's an integral component to Magic in all formats, from Standard all the way to Vintage. Your mana base is just another resource that you have to protect if you want to win...just as Lightning Bolt zaps your life total and Hymn to Tourach mutilates your hand, land destruction screws up your mana base--and like any other strategy, it has its counter-strategies...if your friend is killing you with massive discard, you'd sideboard in Leyline of Sanctity. If your friend is killing you with Armageddon, you sideboard in Sacred Ground. What's the big deal?

234.content: What an irony of fate to have the card named "Balance" as one of the most imbalanced cards ever printed.

One of the most broken cards ever printed, how this made it to 4th edition is beyond me. discard, LD and removal all for 1W, stupidly powerful.This was comboed with Zuran Orb for a one-sided Armageddon with the help of artifact mana, with Mox Diamond to create a cheap Mind Twist, and so on...Although one of the funniest stories about that second combo, printed in the old Inquest, was that somebody dropped down to two cards in his opening hand when he played balance. His opponent promptly dropped three Guerilla Tactics dealing 12 damage on the first turn.
One of my friends told me this card was broken the other day.I called him a fool, and said it was clearly balanced.  To bad I didn't have any shades handy.

Of course, what makes this card ridiculous is its two mana cost. With that, you can play it basically whenever it would benefit you. It definitely deserves a 4.5/5.
I would almost want to splash white into a Madness / Hellbent deck just so that I could combo this with One With Nothing.
Also, a Barren Glory-based deck could benefit from this, since it won't have many permanents out anyway.
Staggeringly powerful and another example of how such a simple and seemingly fair idea can be anything but balanced.
This card is a good way to show that you can have an advantage in magic with more than just sheer number of creatures/lands/cards/etc. you have, and that it's really beutifully complex.

Commenting on Every Card on Gatherer this Weekend ^_^I must say, there is a LOT to say about Balance, but I have many printings to say them with :) The important thing to say about the Alpha one is, that after a long time of thinking I did not like this strange knight in the art nearly as much as the FTV Angel art for it, I have come around to deciding that my favorite Balance art is the Judge Foil Promo. :O The odds of us getting THAT art again anytime soon are very low, but it is a really cool Time-Spiral-esque homage/tribute to the Alpha Balance :) (Yes, I'm aware of Restore Balance's existence: Judge Foil Balance is still better!)

280.content: And what basis did people use that marked this less then 5/5?  Was the fact it can't produce red bother you?
An original dual land, its most notable moment was when it cost Bernard Lestrée the 1994 world championship though Karma.

I think that's the key to understanding why these were printed the way they were and apparently not considred overpowered at the time. Considering how many pure color-hate cards there were in early magic sets (Karma, Angry Mob, Curse of Marit Lage, Wrath of Marit Lage, Flashfires, etc), counting as two land types was thought to be enough of a disadvantage to balance out the convenience. They even go out of their way to underline this in the rules text.  Nowadays, Wizards thankfully doesn't print such cheap boring cards as the aforementioned anymore, and there are many more cards that derive positive effects from you controlling certain land types.
Wait for it."Where's that dual land, bro?""It's right bayou."God, that was stupid.

Card of the Day - Friday, March 29, 2002  
The Birds have been one of the staples of the game since it began, but they were created as an afterthought. Their art was originally supposed to be for Tropical Island, but the bird was too prominent. So Richard Garfield created a card just for the art, and it ended up being the most versatile mana-producing creature ever. 
--Also the creature type was 'Mana Birds', modern versions are just 'Bird'
The greatest mana creature ever printed, to think that this card was created at the last moment when this art came back for Tropical Island...

Does anyone else notice that the text on the card is different in every edition? Alpha has Flying and // after it, Beta has flying at the top, Unlimited says another thing and Revised another and 4th Edition another.
I remember thinking back in the day "That's an active volcano... that doesn't LOOK like paradise to me..."

This is a great example of a card that has pretty much stayed at a constant level of power throughout all of magic's history. Being really good but never broken in any foramt. I don't think any other card can claim that feat as much as this guy, hopefully its return to standard (curretent gone from Innistrad/Return to Ravnica) isn't too far away.

I think we should all thank Mark Poole for drawing the bird too prominent.So regarding the story how the mana birds came to be in the first place, it seems adequate to quote Bob Ross:"We don’t make mistakes here, just happy little accidents."

Will always be a staple in a lot of decks. The ability to ramp on turn one is huge and the fact that you're able to produce any color mana is just the most delicious icing on a tasty cake.@ Ibn_Shisha Unless your opponent has 1 life with no blockers. Not strictly better.

Here is a challenge.  Make a deck that becomes worse when you put black lotus in it. Don't try too hard. Your head might explode.

The question of a deck that does not benefit from its inclusion has finally been answered: 43 land. Really though, for 99.9% of the decks out there, this card provides insane tempo advantage for no cost and should be an auto-include if you somehow find yourself lucky enough to get a hold of one.

You wouldn't play Yawgmoth's Will in white weenie, but you'd play Black Lotus. You wouldn't play Gaea's Cradle in monoblue control, but you'd play Black Lotus. You wouldn't play Wrath of God in Red Deck Wins, but... you see where I'm going with this?

I'll be honest:
If you rated it lower than 5, you are just trolling.
Seriously, this is amazing tempo advantage, and there is zero drawback.

BEST CARD EVER

Whoever didn't give this a 5 is a retard this is an autoinclude on any vintage because when you draw it, it is awesome.

Saying that Yawgmoth's Will is better than Black Lotus is like saying candy is better than money. 
The power 9 are the power 9 for a reason. That reason being that no matter what your combo, no matter what card you want to get to win these will help you. 
Yawgmoth's Will is a great card, don't get me wrong. But it is not as universally awesome as the power 9. Black Lotus is the king of them all because it goes in any deck as said above. Every deck becomes better with the inclusion of this card, with fixes for this card attempted time and time again, with none approaching the original...

The greatest — and most expensive — card of all time!

I lost my fair share of these beautiful babies when everybody still played for ante. The good news was I could always trade a Shivan Dragon, any of the Moxen, a Time Walk, or even a Serra Angel or Sengir Vampire to get it back. Or, much more commonly, I'd just keep playing games against the player who won one and I'd soon enough win something he wanted back bad enough to trade one for one, like a Force of Nature, Gaia's Leige, or Aspect of Wolf! I remember buying two of them for $4 a piece, and everybody thought I was stone cold nuts for spending "so much" on a single card! :D I miss those simpler days (and ante!) and wish I'd known how much they'd eventually be worth... /tear

Black Lotus is certainly powerful, but I think it's power is lessened a bit in EDH/Commander. 
Sure, it would be a great draw during the first few turns, but after say, turn 9-10 when you already have most if not all of the mana you'll need for your deck, this card becomes a dead draw. I think the same thing whenever I see someone include [autocard]Dark Ritual[/autocard] or [autocard]Lotus Petal[/autocard] in their EDH/Commander decks - risky but worth it if you can draw it during the early game.
It would be a great help if you went against someone playing land destruction, or land tap ([autocard]telekinetic sliver[/autocard], [autocard]opposition[/autocard], etc) EDH/Commander decks, or if you were playing charged spells that can only get better with more mana ([autocard]comet storm[/autocard], [autocard]banefire[/autocard]), though. Then it wouldn't be so much of a dead draw in the late game (post turn 10). However, by that point there are also better late-game ramp cards ([autocard]Mirari's Wake[/autocard], [autocard]Mana Reflection[/autocard], etc) so its up to you. Early game advantage or late game staying power?

For those of you who did not play back when this was in the core set, it's important to know a few things:- There were not many ways of dealing damage on the first turn.  This did so, in potentially any color deck.- The game was much slower, and land destruction was plentiful and cheap.  Strip Mine, Sinkhole and Ice Storm are not easy cards to recover from early in the game.  This meant your hand might be close to full often, and you might be taking damage from the vise every turn.- While White had Disenchant, Red had Shatter, and Green had Crumble, Black had next to no ways to permanently deal with artifacts, and Blue could also have problems with this.

When me and my brother were quite new at this game, he cast a creature and slapped a few enchantments, including a Red Ward or something. I Unsummoned it, destroyed all the enchantments. Later in that same game, he cast the creature again, and slapped a few more enchantments on it, including a Blue Ward. I drew another Unsummon, and it sat uselessly in my hand as the Blue Ward laughed in my face and the creature grew in formidability. Ah, those were the days.
If you take a good look at the alpha set, it was like they were trying to build this complicated game based on creatures. But what happened was allot of weak cards and the power 9.
Protects your Serra Angel from Psionic Blast.

The pop-art (yet neo-minimalist) etchings of Blue Ward,  liegemen to the Pollackian legacy, question its own raison d'etre. Is it visual tropes? Is it self-conscious (self-mocking/self-loathing) po-mo nombrilisme? Or is it simply (and solely) a stochastic snapshot sans lexical basis? The color ward cycle can best be examined as artistic interventions against the oppressive humor archetype, whereas the unappealingly desperate musings of Dan Frazier's eponymous series are truly indebted to Jenny Holzer’s oeuvre. Or, as Baudrillard and Guillaume so succinctly state, "What is produced with the romantic turn…is…the…play of…masculine hysteria…of …sexual paradigms that once again must be reinserted in the more general and universal context of a change in the paradigms of otherness."

This is actually a really great card from some point of view, it ranks really high in various categories:
"[i]Most ridiculously unelaborate art[/i]" - [b]Second Place[/b]:
Amy Weber gave us some memorable artworks, among others she drew [autocard]Time Walk[/autocard] and [autocard]Illusionary Mask[/autocard].
But the art she gave us here is rather underwhelming, and its baldness gets outclassed only by [autocard]Word of Command[/autocard].
"[i]Most overshadowed mana fixer[/i]" - [b]Tied First Place[/b] with [autocard]Standing Stones[/autocard]:
Both artifacts prevail over a growing amount of vastly superior cards like [autocard]Mana Cylix[/autocard], [autocard]Prismatic Lens[/autocard], [autocard]Prophetic Prism[/autocard], [autocard]Manalith[/autocard], [autocard]Vessel of Endless Rest[/autocard], [autocard]Spectral Searchlight[/autocard], [autocard]Darksteel Ingot[/autocard], [autocard]Coalition Relic[/autocard], [autocard]Chromatic Lantern[/autocard].
"[i]Most surprisingly weak mana artifact from Alpha[/i]": [b]First Place[/b]:

Yes. Think about it. In Alpha, there were the Moxen, Sol Ring, Black Lotus, and Mana Vault. I don't think there were any other 'Mana Stones'. All of the actually fair and balanced ones? They come from Celestial Prism, and thinking that 3 mana is the right casting cost for Fixing your Colors. The cards that give only 2 colors are meant to be played in specifically 2-colored Decks, and are really the same concept as the 5-color artifacts. That is why I'm willing to attribute most of the artifacts that produce mana or search for lands as coming indirectly from [autocard]Celestial Prism[/autocard]. The list of cards that come from those more powerful artifacts is much shorter but many of those cards are just more power than you quite need, or at least more power than is interesting enough to tell a real story about.

Let's remember again: Vorthos was the main audience intended when the game came out, and they had no real reason to imagine Spike's existence (they didn't know the game would be so popular, remember?). The reason the laces are rare is simply because they have, by the original set's lights, a VERY strange ability. Changing a spell or permanent's color is, well, extremely meta, in the same fashion as Sleight of Mind and Magical Hack. Putting them in rare can be thought of as an attempt to ensure that none of the nuts and bolts--the cards you DID find at common and uncommon--would be drowned out by the arcane oddballs.

Way back during Alpha's development, there was a big argument about how this interacted with Stone Rain.Specifically, Stone Rain says it destroys the land, while this says the land can't be destroyed.  The two cards contradict!  And according to the rules, when two cards contradict, the later one takes precedence, meaning that Stone Rain always wins and this card never does anything.(This led to a rule that a card that prevents something from happening always trumps a card that says it happens.)
Possibly the most fun thing to play on an Inkmoth Nexus. Indestructible 1/1 infecting flier for .

this isn't even remotely narrow and people that think it is just don't know how many varieties of Land Based strategies there are: 
1. Vintage: Play on your [autocard]Mishra's Workshop[/autocard] or [autocard]Tolarian Academy[/autocard] (High Stakes Vintage this works less because it's slow and almost certainly you'd be splashing {W}, not {W} main. Adjusting your deck to be able to cast this more is a GREAT WAY to make such combo decks more fair and fun for Friendly Vintage, and also make your opponents' [autocard]Strip Mine[/autocard] less devastating, particularly if they are running [autocard]Crucible of Worlds[/autocard] with it.
2. Legacy/EDH: Whatever your most KEY color fixing land is: A Filter Land, a Shock Land, [autocard]Reflecting Pool[/autocard], a Vivid Land, City of Brass: Not as many "Combos" in Legacy based off of a Single Land being absolutely balls-to-the-walls BAHROHKAHN, but [autocard]Wasteland[/autocard] is still around for everyone not running [autocard]Blood Moon[/autocard], and this card would be good because it's good against Wasteland even though it 'dies' to Blood Moon. Doesn't stop everything like [autocard]Anathemancer[/autocard], but stops SOME of the LD bleeding, like [autocard]Armageddon[/autocard], [autocard]Jokulhaups[/autocard], that-kinda-stuff, and attacking your opponents' lands is so good that every card that protects lands, even if it's not "Auto-4-of", IS "Auto-Narrowly-Useful". 
3. Modern: [autocard]Dark Depths[/autocard]? [autocard]Thespian's Stage[/autocard]? Would combos like this be less ban-worthy if LD playability was increased and consequently the idea of a Land Enchantment protection was less laughable? Picture a different format than we see today, one where something close to [autocard]Pillage[/autocard] might be heavily played? Oh Yeah. And [autocard]Inkmoth Nexus[/autocard], [autocard]Mishra's Factory[/autocard] (if they changed their minds about Duel Decks' general card legality state? but then further started with just a [autocard]Demonic Tutor[/autocard] Ban from the cards affected??)
4. Standard, or any FNM Format, or any Pizza Night Magic at any given time with untuned decks: Man Lands, from Zendikar Duals to [autocard]Mutavault[/autocard], AND even the Xth Edition ones that are less highly praised but still often used for the heck of it. 
Any card that effects lands is a land that impacts the game significantly. The "play 4 of these on your own and then cast [autocard]Armageddon[/autocard]" route is exctremely rough and crude, AND YET it still sounds pretty attractive to see if I can even just build that deck and save TWO of my lands while destroying ALL of theirs. 
Lands are Legit. Heck I didn't even get around to [autocard]Valakut[/autocard] and even wierder Land interactions. The lists are quite long of the decks that would be happy to see this card.
(I named cards whose interaction with Consecrate Land seemed to me to resemble about the Power Level of the Play that could make an impact there- in some cases I imagined an Alternate Universe of the Format where the cardpools were different than they actually are, but the average "Turn Clock" Power Level of the format was somewhere close to the ballpark of the real world. EVERY single one of these uses is very relevant in Loose EDH, some of these are less feasible to imagine in Higher Powered Formats, like the Man-Duals, but would certainly matter somewhere, like imagine if Man-Duals and this co-existed in Standard: Not good enough for Modern I think, but good enough for Standard Fo Show.)
The basic one-sentence evaluation is that it's a much MUCH Spikier, Narrower, Techier [autocard]Terra Eternal[/autocard]. Being more castable probably counts more in the long run than not protecting every single one of your lands does, *particularly* for those Vintage Combos. This card probably make Strip Mine and Wasteland fairer to have 4 of either in Vintage-with-Friends (Vintage where everyone has to sideboard against Dredge is different). You probably wouldn't run 8 LD Lands in Vintage anyway because you want to play as few lands as possible because you want your mana curve to be supertight and need more attack points and spell effects than mana to kill As Fast As Cardboard Possible.

@D|CK
I hate trolls who think they are hot sh*t because they play for ante and put others down for disliking it. It's extremely disingenuous and not sportsmanlike at all.
Ante is a bad concept. It completely eliminates casual play and turns every game into a fear fest because you might lose your cards. It is [i]supposed to[/i] add excitement and suspense to the game because you might win a card, but I don't find stealing peoples cards much fun at all, especially if it was a close match or a really good game. Makes me feel wrong inside. It also discourages new or unskilled players from playing because they know they will probably lose. Even if they don't care if they lose because they just like to play the game, ante will make them care because something is at stake. Also, ante benefits all those arrogant rich kids who have the money to buy 300 booster packs and get all those [autocard]Black Lotus[/autocard]es. Ante makes playing for fun impossible. Magic should be a casual, fun game that anyone can play. Magic is not poker.
IMO, ante is a terrible rule, but if you play with ante, this card can be good. It is situational in regards that you will only play it if you are winning, and it will either outright win you the game (from your opponent conceding) or you can win an extra card, in the rare exception this backfires on you and you wind up losing. This also, more times than not, just makes your opponent hate you even more than they already do. This is also very black to me.
The problem is that a card like this doesn't actually do anything to help you win the game. It changes nothing about the player's states. It would be much better to run a [autocard multiverseid="86"]Terror[/autocard] instead most of the time.
Even though I hate ante, I will rate purely on objective usefulness of the card. I give it a 1/5, since it is situational (as you must already be winning for it to be practical) and will waste a card slot if you are losing. I like all my cards to be useful whether I'm winning or not.
Powerful card in a ante format, but useless otherwise...I do love the art...
thats a really awesome card. it is really funny.

Ante is not stupid. It does take some chutzpah to play with Ante. 
The reasons for it and against It are pretty much obvious. If you want to hold a special event that you organize by personally contacting 8 people who in a dusty room with bad lighting all agree to everything.....
"Saloon Magic" actually sounds REALLY fun and kinda scary for high-level play.  Imagine winning would score you not just a intangible 'player score', but a REAL CARD :O 
iMO, casual players should NEVER feel shanghaied or obligated to play ante, "Accessibility" is Very Important, and even in "Professional" League play, there should be non-Ante circuits to make sure people can find the level of competitiveness they are comfortable with...
However, I think that it would be REALLY, Freaking, COOL, if for certain very-high-profile events, the Top Eights, Semi-Finals, and Finals of the highest level events, yes I would happy if they brought Ante back to a CERTAIN part of the game.  Maybe even only use it in Legacy and Vintage, but...SOMEwhere I'd like to be able to see some real Showdowns with Epic Stakes. 
It IS NOT for everyone...but if Ante was returned to Legacy and Vintage events, then we could Unban all the Ante cards (except [autocard]Contract from Below[/autocard], obvz), and then Restrict the two Black cards that directly reference the Ante....
well, I think there is some merit to this. It's not like I'd ever advocate Ante at FNM :P

Part of blue's early color pie was victory by tiny pinpricks.  Cards like this, Erosion, Psychic Venom and Prodigal Sorceror lent themselves to the strategy of slow bits of damage adding up to eventually overwhelm the opponent, combined with powerful mana denial like Mana Short, Drain Power, Stasis and Power Sink.Blue has always been a versatile color, and eventually Wizards just stopped printing these kinds of spells in favor of more interesting and aggressive strategies.  But to know how we got here, it's always important to remember past design, both good and bad.

The iconic green pump spell, against which all others will be compared for eternity.  It just teaches you so much about the game, both offensively and defensively, by giving you that extra power to knock out an opposing creature, allowing your own creatures to survive lethal damage, or forcing through that extra bit of damage to win the game.  It teaches you timing, patience, and resource management, because sometimes you have to hold it instead of playing it even though you have mana open.  Sometimes you need to save up mana expressly to be able to play it in response to things.
As you get better at the game, so too does your use of this card evolve with your understanding.  If your opponent knows you have some in your deck, they will sometimes play cautiously because they know you have it, allowing you to play mind games and bluff having it when you don't.  Combined with discard and control elements, you can save multiples in your hand for a fatal attack.  You'll discover synergies for it.  And it's never going to be completely useless, as long as you play green, and you have creatures.
All in all, this is the one card in the [i]Alpha[/i] boon cycle that Wizards got completely right.
This is the perfect balance between being a solid, useful card without being overpowered. A card you could almost always find a time to use in almost any deck.

While on it's face it looks like this grants the same utility to both players, in reality it does not: unless you have an extra turn, your opponent gets a draw phase before you do, meaning they get the benefit before you.  While many decks will be perfectly fine with this, it will also mean that your opponent may draw answers to your threats quickly.It's worth noting that this can be quite synergistic with Black Vise if your opponent has a slow deck, dealing colorless damage or forcing your opponent to overcommit to their board, making them make decisions that might otherwise be inadvisable.

That's pretty dumb. Is [autocard]Black Lotus[/autocard] a bad card because [autocard]Disenchant[/autocard] gets rid of it? Is [autocard]Tolarian Academy[/autocard] a bad card because [autocard]Stripmine[/autocard] gets rid of it? Is every creature in the game without protection from white a bad card because [autocard]Swords to Plowshares[/autocard] gets rid of it? Of course not.
Every card in Magic can be dealt with by one card or another.
This is a card that HAS to be dealt with as soon as it's played.  No one wants to loose cards from their hand at random.  Even decks that rely on graveyard interaction have to cast their [autocard]Yagmouths Will[/autocard] or [autocard]Regrow[/autocard] or whatever before the Specter steals it away.  Even one successful attack with this guy can disrupt an entire game.  You loose a land early on, or that card you just tutored for it's a real setback.
Obviously he looses some of his greatness in formats that don't allow [autocard]Dark Rituals[/autocard], but in any format hes a threat as soon as he hits the board.
Even if I have to wait until my third turn to play him, it's a win win situation no matter what my opponent does.  If you don't have an answer for him in your hand, Im happy to have him hit you for a card turn after turn.  If you do have some kind of removal for him and you get rid of him, well that's one less removal spell you have for my [autocard]Juzam Djinn[/autocard]. 
Sure it would be great if he cost [Black] to cast and was a 10/10 with trample and protection from red and protection from white and vigilance ....  but he's not. and its still a great card.

This card is a decent grinder on its own, though.@Arglypuff: Please note, while Power Surge damages at the beginning of the upkeep, the land count is at the beginning of the turn.  I.e., before untap.  With mana burn gone now, if an opponent has Power Surge, just tap all your lands before the end of the turn before yours, thereby having no untapped land at the beginning of your turn, then untap them all, take no damage, draw your card, gtg.Addendum: Of course, having both out kind of makes that a moot point - damage will be done 1 way or the other.

Note the ABU version of this card is more powerful than later printings, as this card only checks to see if a land is tapped. It does not care if the land was tapped to draw mana, and it does not care if the land was tapped by an external effect (e.g., Twiddle).

Yes, but those non-flyers are not riders, but ground support and thus your band can be blocked by non-flyers.Never understood what was the problem with banding. I just think that they couldn't get it right for computers. Banding had three rules:1. Only one non-banding per attack group.2. Attacking group is blocked as one and can be blocked by any that can block one in the group.3. Player who had banding creature attacking or blocking gets to distribute the incoming damage.It was the 'band with others' that got the situation confusing.All these creatures that give their P/T as +P/+T to attacking or blocking creature when tapped don't work like band. First of all banding is commitment that is done before blockers are announced when the bonus giving is normally done after. Secondly only with a bander gets the defender say how to distribute the damage.But on the other hand, concerning this card: Evasion & banding don't mix very well.
Well, at least it has flying. I think. Does banding with non-flyers allow you to fly?

For everyone who doesn't understand how violated you feel after being hit with one of these, picture this:
You start the game, going second, and before you even get a chance to act or get any land on the field, your opponent plays a [autocard]Swamp[/autocard], [autocard]Black Lotus[/autocard], 2 [autocard]Dark Ritual[/autocard]s and then [autocard]Mind Twist[/autocard] for 7.  They've just knocked out your entire hand and set you back for many turns:
- If you draw a land, you have no spells to cast with it, so it's a dead turn.
- If you draw a spell or creature, you can't play it because you have no land.
Meanwhile, you could be taking tons of damage from [autocard]The Rack[/autocard] or having all semblance of a plan being knocked out every turn by [autocard]Hypnotic Specter[/autocard] or [autocard]Juzám Djinn[/autocard] you can't deal with.
Wizards seems to have recognized how degenerate cards like this can be, in conjunction with fast mana.  This is probably why is random discard, and [autocard]Dark Ritual[/autocard] and its ilk, are gone (or at least costed much less aggressively).  Having no choice of what you discard is an extremely powerful effect, especially when combined with forced discard of multiple cards.  The ability to knock out lands can also completely destroy early-game development, and keep you from executing your game plan completely, which can be extremely hard to overcome.

33.content:
"what was wotc thinking. without the four of rule, (when this was first printed) why would you ever play a land? "
They were thinking that players wouldn't collect the cards so seriously. They knew some cards were much better than the others, but figured that it wouldn't matter because nobody would go out of their way to obtain dozens of them. 
I doubt Richard Garfield would have believed it that the game would still be going strong after nearly twenty years.

They never expected people to have infinite resources, money allowing, like competitive players have these days.  Back in the day overpowered cards like this were balanced by people not having enough cards for it to matter too much.  They quickly learned better.

115.content: Mark Poole didn't make the card, he just illustrated it.

This is actually not a terrible creature in a lot of games, though I prefer Phantom Monster in most situations.  It's playable in limited and provides 4 power with evasion for 4 mana, which can end a game in short order if your opponent has few blockers or removal - and trade with threats like Serra Angel and Sengir Vampire.  Blue was the "air force" color in early Magic, and with a swarm of Flying Men, Phantom Monster, Air Elemental and Mahamoti Djinn protected by countermagic, you could really put some damage on the board and remove everything that posed a threat.  Unstable Mutation also addressed this creature's defensive deficiencies, making it really hard to kill - especially if your opponent was tiptoeing around your countermagic.

119.content:
Back in the day Blue had this strange theme of killing you with little pinpricks, punishing you with little packets of 1 or 2 damage, or tapping your resources, every turn.  [autocard]Psychic Venom[/autocard], [autocard]Prodigal Sorcerer[/autocard], [autocard]Erosion[/autocard] and [autocard]Feedback[/autocard], along with this card, annoyed players when used with [autocard]Drain Power[/autocard], [autocard]Mana Short[/autocard], [autocard]Power Sink[/autocard] and of course [autocard]Mana Drain[/autocard].  These abilities have since moved to black and red.
Blue's methodical kill was annoying to play against, and compromised your opponents' ability to play freely.  However, I think Wizards soon realized that these tactics were too slow to keep up with the other colors.  For this reason, blue's win conditions have switched to milling, and big flying creatures.  After all, they do seem to work better than little conditional and narrow cards like this, which are cute, but are awful in terms of mana curve (especially in the color of counterspells).

Do you guys actually play with the ridiculous new rules that eliminate mana burn? I refuse to play that way, ever. Not for a tournament, not for casual play. Mana burn was part of the game for nearly 20 years for a reason. It forces players to actually make calculated decisions with their resources. Without mana burn, players can just haphazardly tap their lands for mana in a sloppy manner. Mana burn also makes cards like Black Lotus, Sol Ring, and Mana Drain slightly balanced. Seriously, these cards would actually be considerably more powerful - if you can imagine that - without the threat of mana burn. Is this what we want?
Then we have cards like Mana Vault, Mana Crypt, Mishra's Workshop, and the Urza lands. You have to actually think before tapping this cards - if mana burn exists, as it should.
And finally, there's cards like Power Surge, which were obviously designed with the reality of mana burn in mind. Of course, so was Mana Drain - the threat of mana burn was the only thing keeping it even slightly sane!!
Why the hell did WotC throw mana burn on the scrapheap? My guess is it was to simplify the game yet further, for the Pokemon kids. Just like eliminating interrupts was. They have changed Magic: the Gathering far too many times in its short lifespan. Imagine if chess went through zillions of changes every decade? It wouldn't have lasted several centuries, that's for sure.

Many people wonder why Psionic Blast is consider more powerful than Char. The answer is simple. Blue, by tradition, isn't the color of aggression. It's on the other side of Red and Green and thus were designed to be more passive and controlling. Psionic Blast is one of the exceptions where planeswalkers could do direct damage to kill a creature or opponent. Combine with other blue control cards, PB is very dangerous, compare to Char is already in a damage-abundant color. Last but not least, there are also way fewer creatures with protection from blue than red.

Odd.  The errata changes the card's effect dramatically.  Under modern rules, the original card wouldn't save your life if you took lethal damage, because you'd drop below 0 (and die as a state-based action) before you could cast it.  On the other hand, with the original wording, if you took damage from a source multiple times in one turn, Reverse Damage would reverse all of it; the Oracle text doesn't allow that.
Presumably they changed it to prevent the damage because of the rules change that made dying a state-based action; previously you'd only die at the end of the phase, so it could save you if you dropped into negatives.  But that doesn't explain why it's no longer capable of reversing damage retroactively when you've been damaged multiple times by the same source -- or why [autocard]Reverse Polarity[/autocard], which had nearly identical wording to this originally, has an Oracle text that goes the other way (failing to save you from lethal damage, but allowing you to reverse damage retroactively and to cover something that has damaged you multiple times in one turn.)

[autocard]White Knight[/autocard] was superior to [autocard]Grizzly Bears[/autocard] in combat, much like [autocard]Serra Angel[/autocard] was better than [autocard]Air Elemental[/autocard]. [b]Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #64, 2/14/10[/b]
I've played this card a few times way back in the day (I think four of these plus a few [autocard]Zombie Master[/autocard]s filled out the [autocard]Meekstone[/autocard] deck I mentioned a while back), but I didn't really fall in love with it until I started working here.
For many years, I had it firmly planted in my head that Scathe Zombies was going to be the card that appeared in the most consecutive Core Sets—after all, if we're willing to keep printing a vanilla [2B] 2/2, then we're maintaining a pretty consistent power level. Plus, I really love the real-world flavor text from Coleridge. (People seem to think we've discontinued real-world flavor text, but there has been some amount of it in every Core Set. Chances are that you've just stopped paying attention.)
Scathe Zombies didn’t make it into M10—I really loved the idea of a redone [autocard]Nantuko Husk[/autocard] ([autocard]Vampire Aristocrat[/autocard]) at common and we don't really want to do strictly-better cards at the same rarity—and now its down to either [autocard]Giant Spider[/autocard] or [autocard]Giant Growth[/autocard] as the only card to appear in every Core Set (tune into M12 for the winner!). [autocard]Warpath Ghoul[/autocard] and its twin [autocard]Barony Vampire[/autocard] have become the new [2B] black vanilla creatures of choice.
Truthfully, [2B] 2/2 is too weak to be on-curve—it hampers all the two- and three-mana creatures you can make in that color. Scathe Zombies just wasn't holding up well, as we printed [autocard]Bog Raiders[/autocard], [autocard]Blood Vassal[/autocard], [autocard]Quagmire Druid[/autocard], and tons of other commons that are better than him while he was in print. And it's hard to call [autocard]Warpath Ghoul[/autocard] "power creep" with a straight face, as all we did was take a card you'd never really consider playing in constructed and turn it into a slightly better card that you'll still never really consider playing in constructed, even ten years ago—they both essentially rate as "0."
Then again, Scathe Zombies is quite a bit better than [autocard]Mindless Null[/autocard]. Power creep indeed!
They made it through ten core sets with that flavor text intact... no small feat.  Then got kicked out of M10.  Poor Scatheys.

@Aaron_Forsythe: I am a casual player, and I actually think that, within that setting, Scathe Zombies is the quint-essential zombie card. [b]@ Nyktos:[/b]
Well, the toughness 3 of [autocard]Trained Armodon[/autocard] really matters. Since if you look at the M12 statistics, 44 cards have a power of 2, whereas only 13 have a power of 3. That really makes the Armodon quite a powerful card. The second green mana however was removed for multicolor-limited reasons, leaving enough room to also make the black version a bit more powerful.
[b]@ Aaron:[/b]
Although I never really liked the power curve of magic (since power 1 means 20 hits and power 2 means half that much), I never felt happy with 2/2 for 3. In a usual game, the cmc3 slot is what I call the "pants down" slot, where you usually recognize how the game is gonna be. There are cards like [autocard]Tempered Steel[/autocard] makes it obvious that no-fattie will see play. [autocard]Seismic Assault[/autocard] proves that it's some sort of fast combo kill, whereas an [autocard]Pyrexian Arena[/autocard] symbolizes an attrition deck.
But also non-enchantment cards fulfill this criteria. F.e. all the lords cost 3 mana to cast.
Seeing an underwhelming Zombie (even the 3/2 version) in this slot, makes me shiver and I would have rather see a 2/2 Zombie for [1B]. Not only would this card still have the same P/T rating as any zombie token, it would also show that there is no need to give black weaker creatures than white or green. Neither black destruction spells nor reanimation are powerful enough to force a drawback on creatures. In addition, this zombie would really symbolize a mindless minion and would have MUCH more flavor than any [autocard]Glory Seeker[/autocard] or [autocard]Runeclaw Bear[/autocard].
Spealing of these two cards, green should have the cmc3 vanilla creature to use the "pants down" slot for a vanilla creature to show the creature focus of this color.

What can I say that hasn't been said? One of the icons of the game early on. I love that Maddocks was free to imagine and create such a twisted vampire and that WotC let him! This was before Interview with a Vampire and Twilight made kids think that Vampires should look sexy. And it was before WotC had to worry about pleasing the masses. They let the artists inject such originality into their new world and created a unique flavor for their unique game. it would have been much less risky to stick with boring, classic, archetypal fantasy art, but they rolled the dice with a lot of early art and hit a home run. There is no doubt what the color black represents in this game: these vampires are deranged, evil creatures of the night. Anson Maddocks did as much to define the early flavor of Magic as anyone.

@Fert12334That's because this is a 'Mono Artifact' (Look at it's type line). 'Mono' was an old subtype of artifact that inherently required a  to use it's ability, so it only had one use per turn (hence the 'Mono'.) Sort of like how the land subtype 'Forest' inherently adds ": Add  to your mana pool." to what ever land it's on. The alternative was 'Poly Artifact' that did not need the  and so could be activated multiple times a turn. Pyramids being one of these. And other was 'Continuous Artifact' that needed no activation, but had static or triggered abilities, like Enchantments. One you should be familiar with is Howling Mine, which only recently left Standard. The line on the Mine about only if is untapped on the more recent versions is also something that was part of the Continuous line of artifacts, in that they lost their effect when tapped.

179.content: See, this is what art looks like. That large white space in the corner is "negative space", as artists call it. It gives perspective and balance. New art (mostly) doesn't have negative space, just ultra-saturated colors all over the place, like some kind of visual MSG to stimulate your optical nerves to exhaustion. I could see new kids looking at this art and feeling their minds being blown by all that blank white space, like it was some kind of deafening silence in contrast to the extremely active, angular, Tom-Cruise-action-thriller photographs they've been churning out for the last decade.

For example from modern sets, [autocard]Wall of Frost[/autocard] is a modern take on this card that is much better. Costing 1UU, it is in a colour that is more interested in a defensive creature, and it can "handle" two creatures at once. This wall is red because the original idea of the card was a natural mountain formation of stone like a cliffwall.

Perhaps the biggest flaw with the wall creature type is that all walls are bound by the same "can only block 1 creature" rule as other creatures. I mean, if a wall stretches all the way into the horizon in both directions, it's downright unflavorful for the rest of the creatures it can't block to simply walk around it.If walls aren't ever going to attack (unless you do something crazy like rolling stones or some such), I think it's perfectly reasonable to let them block more than one creature. Very few walls have more than 2 power, and almost all of them have 0. I'm not saying all walls should be able to block all creatures, but maybe just 1 additional creature would be nice and people would actually use walls in non-casual games.
@Allmighty_AbacusIn my opinion, all walls should have a built in palace guard ability. But thats just me. It makes sense, to seize the castle you need to send your whole army at the wall.

Excerpt from the Wikipedia entry:
In [i]You Can Call Mi'cha[/i], Paul Simon touches on the theme of the emammothculation faced by middle-aged Magic players. The first verse reflects the titular character's frustration with wanting to keep his unique identity instead of being lumped in with other pachyderms.
In the chorus, he finds solace in sharing his experience with another alpha card.
The second verse describes Dwarven Recruiter's frustration with how Dwarves never got the support that Goblins did, appearing briefly as recently as Shadowmoor block only to never be heard from again. The highlights of the Dwarves glorious history are touched on briefly.
Finally, we return to the titular character in a modern magic environment. Although he is confused at first, he finds salvation upon discovering the "combo" of R&D's Secret Lair and Infinite Reflections, allowing him to maintain his mammoth-hood and meet others just like him!

It seems to me like Wheel of Fortune is a lot better than Timetwister. I mean, Wheel of Fortune is in the color that empties its hand the quickest, while Timetwister is in the color that empties its hand the slowest. Maybe Timetwister is better in some combo deck or something, but I think that, altogether, Wheel of Fortune is a better card.
